--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@c...> wrote:
> > Shimon Whiteson here at UT has been working on a method of feature
> > selection that slowly adds new inputs over the course of the run
and
> > has had some initial success.  You might want to try this with
your
> > high-input domain as well.  He generally found it beneficial to
start
> > out with very few inputs attached and let NEAT attach inputs
randomly
> > through a special mutation that connects a disconnected input to
all
> > the outputs.  The rate of that mutation is somewhere between 0.05
and
> > 0.2 in his experiments but it's still an empirical question what's
> > best.  It would be interesting to see if it helps in OCR.
> 
> That's very clever indeed! How does the pick the initial inputs?
Just 
> randomly over the set of possible inputs?
> 

Here's how he picks the initial inputs:  In the initial population,
for each member of the population, each input has a 1/(number of
inputs) chance of being connected.  Also the bias is always connected
to the outputs.  So on average each network has the bias and one other
input connected.  Any network with only the bias connected is forced
to have one other connection connected.  So the initial population is
minimal but diverse.

Here's another thing Shimon suggested:  Instead of training one big
OCR network, train a separate network for each letter.  And do the
training separately, i.e. an "is it a 'b'?" network and a separate "is
it an 'a'?" network.

ken
